so it isn't quite that simple. Since the numbers/mechanics/visuals of some champs change each patch, the game state is actually different from when the mode came back originally. They explained this recently in a post, but basically each time they run a game mode it has to go through testing again to check for bugs/interactions/balance. It's not as simple as 'turning it on'

MalrothDragonia has this right. 

One of the downsides of patching out balance, champion, and item changes every two weeks is that those changes end up grinding up the nuts and bolts of League's game modes. 

As a practical example, since the last run of One For All, Zoe didn't exist. So in preparation to relaunch the mode in 8.6, testers noticed that one Zoe could see another Zoe's W pickups, but was unable to pick them up. 

Game designers did work to make sure that any of one team's Zoe's could pick up allied pickups, with some follow up to get the drop rates to feel fun and semi-balanced. Then we play-tested, iterated a bit, and now we are running it through a QA test, which could lead to more development and testing. 

This is one case, for one champion, and we tend to have many of these sorts of cases for every mode that we release, even including some of the original modes like Ascension and Poro King. It varies per mode, but unfortunately, to ensure a quality experience for you all, no mode can just be turned on at a moment's notice.

I know, I read the article, and I in fact am one of the people that didn't come back until just recently. I was waiting for URF to come back, but it never did. That's why I spent so long away. Normal League is super stressful, but URF was a way to de-stress that ARURF just doesn't fulfill.

My question is though in direct correlation to this reasoning is what if its run through QA test and works fine but when launched live an in game bug occurs causing that specific champion to be unplayable?

I get the time and effort it takes and I'm taking into account how many different scenarios can occur, but if Zoe is a champion that needed extra treatment to work through to make sure its perfect in game when that RGM is live, and a bug occurs that wasn't originally seen and that champ become unplayable for most of the time of the event, doesn't that kind of taint the game mode a bit? 

Another question, how would keeping the same game mode live not keep from people not playing it? Im not disagreeing that you can't just turn a game mode on, because I understand it's not that easy but when new game modes went from patch to patch, even with bugs it kept the game fresh. Every week I'd play a brand new game mode and when I would take tough losses in ranked and be bored of ARAM it offered less stagnation. I'm personally not a fan of Blood Moon Hunt, but because it offers a different take on the game I dont mind playing it a bit here and there. If this game mode stayed live a whole patch though I know I wouldn't play it after a good week. Even URF I would get bored of after like 2 weeks and I absolutely love URF. I know I dont speak for everyone and I'm only a minor percentage of the whole, but how would keeping the same random game live for that long not become boring after a certain amount of time. Is there anyway to ensure the longevity of people playing that game mode for a long time? I'm just curious on how other people feel about this.
